JACKSON'S lectures on Persian Poetry, delivered on
the Turnbull Foundation, are over. It is a remarkable tribute to a
man's powers as a lecturer when we consider how closely and personally Professor Jackson brought home to us the lives and work of
the poets of far-away Siram. A possibly more remarkable tribute was
paid to the memory of Omar. Last Wednesday week, in the midst
of a driving snow-storm a throng which crowded McCoy Hall to the
doors came to hear the lecture on Omar and his predecessors. It is
perhaps worht mentioning that at least two members of English
VA.-- :..' *4sile•
Literature I, thought last week that Chaucer's reference to "Omer"
referred not to the greatest Grecian Poet, but to the best-known poet of Persia!
The course was interesting; at times fascinating. The graphic description given us of
the silent ruins of the once gorgeous palaces of Cyrus and Xerxes will continue long in the
memories of some of us.

OLLO WING the offer made by the Class of 1902 of medals for the
winning class Lacrosse Team comes a similar offer of medals to the
winning class Track Team—the four members of the teams to be
picked from the Junior and Freshman Classes respectively. The
letter comes from a number of Alumni interested in the welfare of
the University and in the maintenance of her interest in athletics.
Their offer is a kind and generous one, and it is to be hoped it will
be met with in the spirit it deserves.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

3

HE Johns Hopkins Cotillon Dance, held two weeks ago, while very
enjoyable, was marred by one thing for which there was really no
excuse. The state of the floor was, dreadful,—not that it was not
smooth enough,—but both in the hall itself and in the corridor there
was a great deal of dust and dirt. Fortunate was the girl who had
no train! Then, too, why should the dances begin before nine?
They never do begin at eight-thirty, as scheduled. Most people will
not come so early, and the first half hour must be decidedly dreary
for those who do happen to come on time. Still, in spite of these
objections, the dance was decidedly a success.

An issue of the NEws-LETTER should have appeared last Friday, but Editors, like other
mortals, are liable to fail, particularly when the Dean's and other essays are on our hands.
.We regret the unavoidable delay, which we trust will not occur again, this year at any rate.

BALTIMORE, MD., January 27, 1908.
The Editor of the NEWS-LETTER,
Johns Hopkins University:
MY DEAR SIR :—In order to enable the track sports at the University to maintain their
position with the other spring sport, Lacrosse, and bring forth candidates who will by their
work in the different sets of gatnes held at times during the winter and spring months, we
have this proposition to make to the under-classmen: That a relay race between teams selected
from the Junior and Freshman Classes be run at the set of games to be held by the 'Varsity
Track Team on February 29th, 1908, for which we offer medals to the winning team.
This is done so that more enthusiasm may be brought forth in favor of track sports,
and aid the coach and captain in getting out candidates for the track squad from the underclasses.
The conditions upon which we make the above offer, are as follows:
(1). That the candidates for each of said teams shall become candidates of the 'Varsity
Track Squad, and shall train regularly under the direction of the 'Varsity coach and captain.
(2). That the teams shall be picked by the track coach and 'Varsity captain, and in so
doing they shall have just as much reference to the candidates' attendance at practice and
faithfulness at training as the running ability.
(3). That each team shall be composed of four men.
(4). That the distance of said race shall be one mile.
Very truly yours,
R. CURZON HOFFMAN, JR.,
W. CORNWELL SMITH,ARTHUR R. PADGETT,
J. FRED. HUNTER,
Jos. TOWNSEND ENGLAND,
LUTHER M. R. WILLIS,
THEODORE E. STRAITS,
EDMUND C. LYNCH,
GEORGE A. STEWART.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

4

A VISITOR.
The past summer had many bright days for
me, for I spent June, July, August, and
September on my father's farm in Frederick
County. The day which will always remain
in my memory as the never-to-be-forgotten,
fun-giving day is that on which "My Visitor,"
as my father calls him, came.
In the early morning and forenoon I worked
in the fields, hay-making, and in return for
my morning's labor I was promised the use of
our excellent riding horse for that evening.
In the afternoon I noticed my horse had lost
a shoe, so I took him down to the village to
be shod. While waiting at the blacksmithshop, I was called over to the country store
to get a 'phone .message. This message was
rather strange; "Tell Mr. Mun a y that
So-and-so will be up on the evening train,"
the clerk said that he did not catch the name.
After attending to some errands in the
village, I rode out to my home and delivered
the message. No one in the family had given
any one out of the vicinity an invitation and
no one knew who was coming and we all were
more or less amused at the curtness of such a.
message. Much to my sorrow I was informed
that they would need the horse promised me,
since he was what we termed the "station
wagon horse," to take the large dayton to the
station and bring back the visitors. No one
knew whether there really was anyone coming
or someone was one playing a joke on us so
we prepared for three people. The spare
rooms were all ready, supper on the table for
the guests, or rather, unexpected visitors, and
everything was prepared for their arrival.
About time for the train to come in the
man drove down with my horse and the
station wagon. When the train came in he
looked around for our visitors but none came
and he was just about to drive off when the
freight agent called out. Here's your party.
Of course, the whole family was anxious to
know who was coming and all were out
watching for their arrival. I, being a little
more anxious and put out than the rest, was
the first to find out that no one was on the
front seat of the wagon but the driver. I ran
out to the front and asked who it was and he
said, "They are in the back." I looked and
saw only a crate and asked him "Where?"

"There," said he, pointing to the box I took
it out and in doing so my hand slipped in a
crack and touched a fuzzy, hairy something
which gave a low whine. Then it dawned
upon me what it was. It was a through-bred
St. Bernard puppy promised me by a friend
sometime before. While very much put out
and provoked, the whole family at once saw
the funny side of the affair and my mother
said, "My best bed linen all put out on the
beds for a dog."
I however, was not disappointed, for after
I had made my dog comfortable I went and
got my horse and had a long, beautiful, and
never-to-be-forgotten horseback ride.—M.

THE DANCE.
The second dance of the Cotillon Club was
held on Friday, the thirty-first of January.
From the point of view of the students, it was
one of the most successful ever given. Everybody was there, and "everybody was happy."
Old and distinguished Alumni danced
around and bumped into green young Freshmen and then the Freshmen, not to be outdone,
bumped into them. A few professors were
there, and great excitement was aroused when
a foolish Junior broke up one of them. Suppressed whispers were heard in the hall, and
the young lady who was broken up remarked
in a wise tone:
"I'll bet you flunk your next French
exam."
Of course, we can't say just who the professor was, but that night he wore his usual
cheery smile.
And then there was the barn dance. Some
knew it and some didn't, but everybody danced
it. A few beginners got tumbles, but soon
they got on to it and everybody was in the
swing, perspiring and grinning together.
A few of the professors' wives were there to
chaperon and lend dignity to the occasion.
The students owe to these ladies a debt of
thanks for their unfailing support of the dances.
All in all, it was a great success, and credit
is due to the Cotillon Club for the care taken.
May the next dance on April 24th be as good
as the last one.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE MUSICAL CLUBS.
The Musical Clubs are at last taking on
definite shape and beginning the season's
round of concerts. On the twenty-second of
January a very successful concert was given at
the Johns Hopkins Medical School. A large
proportion of the clubs turned out. The Glee
Club, under the able leadership of Mr. Ruth,
reminded one of the palmy days of old when
thd clubs were in such a flourishing condition.
It is with pleasure that we can note that once
more they seem to arouse the same enthusiasm
among the students and are in such excellent
shape.
On the twenty-sixth of February a concert
will be given at St. David's Church, at Roland
Park, and two others will be given in the near
future, one at the Sparrow's Point Club and
the other at the Sheppard-Enoch Pratt Hospital. The dates for these, however, have not
yet been decided upon.
Then, on the thirteenth of March comes
their red-letter day. A joint concert with the
Woman's College will be held at McCoy Hall.
This will be the first large concert held in
Baltimore by the Musical Clubs for some time,
and everybody in the University should be
there, and bring someone with them, too.
This should be a great success, and the
students should support it.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

POETS OF TODAY.
INTRODUCTORY.
I purpose to write a series of sketches of
those living men who by the high and enduring quality of their work are justly entitled to
the name of Poets, as distinguished from the
ever-swarming hoard of writers of verse.
Thirty years ago such an undertaking as mine
would have been, and was, a task involving
deep and thorough knowledge of the works of
several of the greatest poets of the nineteenth
century. In 1877 Tennyson, Browning,
Arnold, Swinburne, Rossetti and Morris were
all alive and all writing. Today but one of
this illustrious group is alive and he has
passed the alloted time of life.
In glancing over the literary field today, we
find that no one man can lay claim to
absolute pre-eminence. There is, with the
exception of Swinburne, (of whose work by
the way I do not intend to treat in this series)
no great poet living; that is, great as Keats or
as Tennyson was great; but there are several
poets of recognized worth and ability. Of
these most are among the last survivors of
the Age of Tennyson, "the Victorian Age"
and two are of the new era which is slowly
and uncertainly beginning to shape itself
today.
Of the Victorian Poets Mr. Austin Dobson
is the best known, and is most conspiciously
identified with the past. Mr. William Watson's greatest work—his elegies, his epigrams,
and such poems as a "A Child's Hair"—
were written long ago. Mr. Alfred Austin,
writer of charming prose and infinitely less
pleasing verse, is associated with the literary
squabbles of the '70's. Mr. Meredith has
been so long considered as the greatest living
novelist that the far-off days when he wrote
"Love in a Valley" and "Modern Love"
seem to belong to. another existance. His
transformation is indeed marvellous. It is
hard to believe that the author of "Diana of
the Crossways" could have written "The
Shaving of Shagpot;" it is equally difficult to
reconcile the facts that "Love in a Valley,"
and "The Egoist" are from the same pen.
But this is a digression, and we must continue
our enumeration. In 1900 Rudyard Kipling
was unquestionably the presiding genius of

English letters. The novelty of his manner
as of his matter gave him that eminence. But,
in the words of a writer at the time, he was
"the genius of the moment" and is so no
longer. Mr. Andrew Lang, perhaps the
most versatile of modern authors, has for long
laid aside his poetic pen, but the work of such
a true poet cannot die and the author of
"Helen of Troy," 'Andromache,"and—more
than all—of the lovely lyric "Who wins his
love," is indeed "a living part of English
Song."
All these men are writers who have made
their reputations in the past, some, as Mr.
Meredith, half a century ago, though perhaps like him only now receiving that
recognition which their own generation fail
to bestow upon them. But beside them,
there is one poet today, in whom we can
clearly see traces of lineal descent from Keats
and from Tennyson—who is the fulfillment
of the wish expressed long since that a poet
would arise combining in his genius the
tongue of Tennyson and a dramatic instinct
which the author of "Becket" had not.
Finally, and perhaps far from least among
these writers, is Mr. Alfred Noyes, of whom
great things are promised. He is as yet very
young, but his youth doth promise much,
and the author of "A Night at St. Helena"
and "The Barrel Organ" may live to be a
shining and abiding light among the stars of
English poetry.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE GEORGE WASHINGTON MEET.
Hopkins did herself proud in the first
annual meet of George Washington University,' held January 25th, in Convention Hall,
Washington, for not only did her men score
a goodly number of points in the open events,
but they came home as holders of the
Southern Championship in the two mile
relay.
There were only two teams in the race.
Virkinia withdrew a few days before the meet,
and only George Washington was left to contest the supremacy and they didn't once get
within sight of the prize. "Polly" Brenton,
who led off, came in fully 40 yards ahead of
the man who was trying to run against him.
Burgan the second man was just as rapid,
or his opponent was just as slow, for he
doubled the distance between them. "Mich"
Griffith kept up the good work, and finally
George Stewart, probably with memories of
last year's race against Virginia floating in
his head, "hit up" the pace that killed hope
in the hearts of Washington rooters, and
romped in at least 200 yards ahead.
"Dutch" Breyer, in the mile, had a reputation to live up to, for all Washington is still
talking of the cross-country race that he and
Polly won so handily on New Year's Day.
But "Dutch" was equal to it. The only scratch
man in the event, he passed an opponent or
two every lap, and finally finished in a position a disinterested spectator would have
called second. The judges, however, gave
the place to a man that had surely been
lapped, and Breyer had to be content with a
bronze medal.
Baily got a second place in the 50-yard
dash, open. He won his heat, beat out
Stollenwerck by a foot in the semi-finals, and
was placed in the finals.
Bridgeman, with a handicap of six inches,
got over 10 feet in the pole vault, and would
probably have gone even higher, had he not
broken his pole, and received a fall that so
incapacitated him that he could no longer do
himself justice.
For the other field events, the men were
unplaced, though Schneeberger made a strong
bid for a place in the high jump. There
were no entries in the shot put, for neither
Michael nor Walters, recognized as the best

7

men in the University, have made a pretense
at training, and in accordance with his wellestablished policy, Mr. West did not enter
them.
There was quite a crowd of Hopkins men
at the meet, and on several occasions they
made their presence felt with a rousing
Hullabaloo.
TRACK NOTES.
The months of February and March promise
to be especially rich in track events, for, in
addition to the meets that the 'Varsity will
hold, there will be two open meets at the
Fifth Regiment Armory and several in Washington of a similar character. The annual
Hopkins meet will be held in the "cage" on
Saturday, February 29th. Owing to the size
of the cage, we cannot hope to have as large
a meet this year as we had last year. But it
is hoped that the quality of the events will fill
in this gap. Entry blanks have been sent out
to the colleges and prep. schools in Maryland,
Virginia and Washington, and many of the
best local athletes have expressed their intention of entering, as the whole meet will be
held from scratch. The events will be as
follows:
50-yard dash (open).
50- yard dash (interscholastic).
440-yard dash (open).
440-yard dash (interscholastic).
880-yard run.
Mile run.
16-pound shot-put.
Pole vault.
High jump.
Broad jump.
A number of relay races will also be arranged.
March 14th has been decided as the date on
which the Hopkins open cross-country run
will be held. The course, which will be about
five and one-half miles long, will start and
end at Homewood.
Stollenwerck, of the 'Varsity track team,
has been selected by Mr. Joseph England as
one of the four men who will form the Baltimore team, in the Inter-City relay race

8

THE NEWS-LETTER.

between this city and Washington, which
will be held in the Federal Meet at Washington, February 15th. The associates of the
Hopkins man will be John Harrison, of
Mount Washington, Zeigler, of M. A. C.,
and Ranser, of Western Maryland.

THE BANQUETS.
When this issue of the NEWS-LETTER
appears two, at least, of the Class Banquets
will have taken place—the Senior Banquet on
Wednesday, February 12th—and the Junior
Banquet the following day. There has been
a good deal of excitement in a quiet way
around the University and the Juniors have
compelled several Freshmen to give their
word not to attend any banquet of their Class
this week. So readily, indeed, have these
promises been forthcoming from the Freshmen that a suspicion has arisen in the minds
of the more judicious of the upper-classmen
that there will be no Freshmen Feed this
week. Just what will happen we don't know,
but things promise to be pretty lively around
here for some days to come. Fuller accounts
of the Banquets will appear in our next issue,
which, by the way, will probably appear next
Friday.

ALUMNI NOTES.
Messrs. Stevens T. Mason, Horace Whitman
and Thomas Cadwallader have established a
law firm with offices in the American Building.
Mr. W. E. F. Armstrong is with the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad.
Mr. Thomas Campbell is still teaching at
St. James' School, St. James, Washington
County, Md.
Mr. A. A. Reinhardt, 'OZ, is at Penn Department of Forestry, Mount Alto, Pa.
Mr. Lyall Gunts, '05, recently took unto
himself a wife.
Fred. Tough, last year's lacrosse captain, is
studying at Columbia.

Harry King Tootle, '03, has resigned as
assistant advertising manager of The Kansas
City Journal to associate himself with The
Baltimore News, the paper with which he was
connected before going to Kansas City nearly
three years ago. Mr. Tootle arrived in Baltimore February 1st.
Thomas Gresham Machen, '06, and Thomas
Owings, '05, have been back in town for a
few days from Boston "Tech."
James Morfit Mullen, '02, has been elected
a director of the International Trust Company.
Mr. W. 0. B. Harding, '07, is a missionary
in Japan.
Out in Fairmount, W. Va., may be found
"Jimmy" Hunter, '07, track captain, '06.
"Jimmy" is in the employ of the Fairmount
Coal Company, and is learning to survey their
coal fields. He was one of the first to go into
the Monongah mines to carry relief after that
terrible disaster a few weeks ago.

NOTES AND CLIPPINGS.
Among the best of the papers which have
lately come to us among the exchanges are
the Harvard Monthly and the Transylvanian,
of Kentucky University, both of which are
excellent examples of what purely literary
college monthlies should be.
The Poet —"Have you found space for my
poem yet?"
The Editor—"No, but I will as soon as the
office boy empties the waste basket."
—St. Mary's Collegian.
The Fresh stood on the burning deck;
As far as we can learn
It did not seem to hurt him,
He was too green to burn.
—Western Maryland College Monthly.
Love is a funny thing.
Just like a lizard.
Curls its tail over its back,
And creeps into your gizzard.
— Ex.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

GEORGE MEREDITH.
[The celebration of the eightieth anniversary of
George Meredith's birth was an event of "almost national importance" (to use the words of one writer
on the subject.) In spite of divers opinions the
majority of readers have agreed that Mr. Meredith's
first great novel "The Ordeal of Richard Feverel"
still remains his masterpiece. The following short
essay on that novel will therefore be appropriate at
this time. The author has a thorough acquaintance
with the works of the novelists of the Victorian
period and his estimate of the greatest novel of the
greatest living English writer will, we feel sure,
prove of interest to many readers.—En.]

RICHARD FRVERAL.
Richard Feverel is generally considered Mr.
Meredith's masterpiece. He has taken a story,
terrible in itself, and he has made it more
terrible by his fearless way of handling it.
The plot is rather complicated, but the main
points are these: Richard, the son of Sir
Austin Peveral, runs away and marries without his father's consent. It is a love match,
pure and simple. Sir Austin refuses to see
his new daughter, but from a sense of justice,
gives his son an income sufficient to support
her properly. After the honeymoon, Richard
conies to London,leaving his wife. In London
he meets a woman—`'an enchantress"—Bella,
her name is, and proves unfaithful to his wife.
Afterwards, overtaken by a wild storm of
remorse, he does not feel worthy to return to
his wife, whom he still loves, so he travels on
the continent. Finally, hearing that a former
friend, Lord Mountfalcon, has been paying
doubtful attentions to his wife, he returns to
England. Meanwhile, Lucy, his wife, has
met Sir Austin and been reconciled with him
and is living at Raynham Abbey, the home of
the Feverels. Now Richard returns to England and goes to Raynham, where, after long
years, he sees his wife and child. The reconciliation is complete, but not so Richard's
ordeal. He must leave his wife in this
supreme hour and meet Lord Mountfalcon.
He tears himself away from his wife and goes
to France. Here he fights Lord Mountfalcon
and is seriously wounded. His wife and
father hear where he is and come to him. But
the long strain has been too much for Lucy;
she cannot stand the hours of watching and
anxiety. She succumbs to brain fever just as
Richard recovers. She dies and Richard lives.
The tragedy is complete.

9

The plot is complete and perfect. There are
no dangling or lost threads. With the death
of Lucy we lose all interest—the book is
finished. Mr. Meredith does not commit the
mistake of Thackeray in the Newcomer—of
adding several chapters to a novel already
completed. To some people the plot appears
unnatural, but these are the people who are
unable to appreciate and understand the
characters.
All the characters, with the possible exception of Sir Austin, are real, are people all of
us have met. That Sir Austin, with his
Scientific Theory, Aphorisms, System and the
rest, could exist, seems to me impossible.
That a real man, with human feeling, could
look at that last supreme tragedy and turn
away complaining that his grandson is fed by
a bottle, is beyond the bounds of human
imagination. To Sir Austin life was but a
complex system, of which he and his were
mere passive members, but with their duty to
their race to fulfil. This was his goal in life.
Richard's wife was dead. His son was the
future lord of Raynham Abbey, and to him
all must be sacrificed. The story is called a
History of a Father and Son, and the father,
in order that the story may exist, is made
unnatural.
Richard is the most misjudged character in
the book. Some people cannot understand
why he refused to return to his wife. Two
reasons could have prompted his course of
action: One, the fact that .for purely selfish
reasons he did not wish to go back to her, he
was tired of her. The second is the true
reason, the reason expressed in those immortal lines, "May God give me the purity to
be worthy of the good in her, and give her the
patience to find , out the good in me."
Richard was governed by a high sense of
honor. For a moment Bella had swept him
off his feet, but his better nature was bound
to assert itself. When Richard came to his
senses he was conscious of being unworthy to
return to his wife. He felt that he had sinned
and must pay the price of his sin. He must
pass through his ordeal. He goes a7way.
Tormented by a guilty conscience he travels,
but always he feels compelled and forced on
by a high sense of honor. Hearing of Lord
Mountfalcon's attention to his wife, he returns

10

THE NEWS-LETTER.

to England. Then comes the crucial test and
Richard comes out triumphant. His life's
happiness may be wrecked, but, having sinned
once, and expiated his sin, he will hereafter
stand clear in his own mind. He goes to
France and the rest ensues.
The other characters of the book are less
important, but none the less powerful. Adrian
is a magnificent portrait of a type well known
in society. He is not confined to England;
wherever there is a refined and polished state
of society, there are Adrians.
Lucy is womanly, intensely womanly. She
can give up her all to a man and then, when
deserted, can pardon and condone his faults.
Lady Blandish and Mrs. Berry form a queer
antithesis. Both are people met with in everyday life. Lady Blandish seems to be a character created by Mr. Meredith to lend him
support when he finds his story lagging or his
characters grown weak.
But one of the strongest and truest characters in the entire book is Clare. Her story is
true, terribly and sweetly true. Married to a
man whom she does not love, she must keep a
brave face to the world till the long-wished-for
peace comes to her. Dickens may appeal to
the emotions of many by the careful and wellcalculated phrases of Old Curiosty Shop;
Thackeray may move many hearts by the
death of Colonel Newcome; Charles Read may
bring tears to many eyes by that story of a
life full of sorrow and suffering, and yet inspired by a divine hope—The Cloister and
the Hearth—the true story of a great man.
Yet to me none of these have the same depth
of feeling and pathos expressed in that one
chapter—'Clare's Dairy. Mr. Meredith handles
a simple fact in a simple manner. It is so
simple, it is true, so true, that to read it
brings tears.
The Ordeal of Richard Feverel is not one
tragedy but a series of them. Everything is
the natural consequence of what has gone before it. The characters are driven on as by
Nemesis. The "System" could have but one
• result.
From the first that was apparent. Mr.
Meredith appreciated this when, after the
marriage, Adrian says," "So die the System!
And now let the prophets roar! He dies
respectably in a marriage bed, which is more

than I should have told of the monster."
Mean-time, he gave the cake a dramatic tap,
'I'll go sow nightmares." After Iliad read the
first dozen chapters I realized that some great
tragedy was inevitable. It is a book of suffering. Even Sir Austin suffered in silence.
The book is remarkably strong in its hold
upon the reader. A lady once told me that
she first read it when crossing the Atlantic.
When she finished the last chapter sbe took
the bobk, and in sheer anger threw it far out
into the ocean. The genuine power of the
book is well shown by this incident. No book,
unless its power were real, and were accomplished with real people in a real plot, could
produce such an effect.
The tragedy in Richard Eererel is not in
Lucy's dying, it is in Richard's living.
"Have you ever noticed the expression in the
eyes of blind men? That is just how Richard
looks, as he lies there silent in his bed—striving to image her on his brain." There is
the real tragedy in the book.
The place of Richard Feverel in English
Literature is hard to define. That it is
literature and of the highest type, there is no
doubt. Many consider The Egoist by Mr.
Meredith the superior of Richard Feverel, but
I do not feel that the two books are to be
compared. I consider Richard Feverel the
masterpiece of Mr. Meredith and one of the
greatest novels in the entire language.
Mr. Meredith's style is naturally abstruse
and difficult to read, but he is at his best.
When I finished The Egoist, I felt that I had
accomplished quite a task, but when I finished
Richard Feverel my first thought was to read
it over again. The style here is superior to
that of any of Mr. Meredith's other novels,
with the possible exception of Diana of the
Cross-ways.
No praise can be too high for the merit of
the novel. The faults are not easily perceived.
The narrative is very slow in progressing. It
is practically half through before the real
story commences. But this space is not wasted.
We are prepared for the tragedy to come; yet
when it does come, we are stunned by its
truth.
SW.

JACKSON'S lectures on Persian Poetry, delivered on
the Turnbull Foundation, are over. It is a remarkable tribute to a
man's powers as a lecturer when we consider how closely and personally Professor Jackson brought home to us the lives and work of
the poets of far-away Siram. A possibly more remarkable tribute was
paid to the memory of Omar. Last Wednesday week, in the midst
of a driving snow-storm a throng which crowded McCoy Hall to the
doors came to hear the lecture on Omar and his predecessors. It is
perhaps worht mentioning that at least two members of English

Literature I, thought last week that Chaucer's reference to "Omer"
referred not to the greatest Grecian Poet, but to the best-known poet of Persia!
The course was interesting; at times fascinating. The graphic description given us of
the silent ruins of the once gorgeous palaces of Cyrus and Xerxes will continue long in the
memories of some of us.

OLLO WING the offer made by the Class of 1902 of medals for the
winning class Lacrosse Team comes a similar offer of medals to the
winning class Track Team—the four members of the teams to be
picked from the Junior and Freshman Classes respectively. The
letter comes from a number of Alumni interested in the welfare of
the University and in the maintenance of her interest in athletics.
Their offer is a kind and generous one, and it is to be hoped it will
be met with in the spirit it deserves.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

3

HE Johns Hopkins Cotillon Dance, held two weeks ago, while very
enjoyable, was marred by one thing for which there was really no
excuse. The state of the floor was, dreadful,—not that it was not
smooth enough,—but both in the hall itself and in the corridor there
was a great deal of dust and dirt. Fortunate was the girl who had
no train! Then, too, why should the dances begin before nine?
They never do begin at eight-thirty, as scheduled. Most people will
not come so early, and the first half hour must be decidedly dreary
for those who do happen to come on time. Still, in spite of these
objections, the dance was decidedly a success.

An issue of the NEws-LETTER should have appeared last Friday, but Editors, like other
mortals, are liable to fail, particularly when the Dean's and other essays are on our hands.
.We regret the unavoidable delay, which we trust will not occur again, this year at any rate.

BALTIMORE, MD., January 27, 1908.
The Editor of the NEWS-LETTER,
Johns Hopkins University:
MY DEAR SIR :—In order to enable the track sports at the University to maintain their
position with the other spring sport, Lacrosse, and bring forth candidates who will by their
work in the different sets of gatnes held at times during the winter and spring months, we
have this proposition to make to the under-classmen: That a relay race between teams selected
from the Junior and Freshman Classes be run at the set of games to be held by the 'Varsity
Track Team on February 29th, 1908, for which we offer medals to the winning team.
This is done so that more enthusiasm may be brought forth in favor of track sports,
and aid the coach and captain in getting out candidates for the track squad from the underclasses.
The conditions upon which we make the above offer, are as follows:
(1). That the candidates for each of said teams shall become candidates of the 'Varsity
Track Squad, and shall train regularly under the direction of the 'Varsity coach and captain.
(2). That the teams shall be picked by the track coach and 'Varsity captain, and in so
doing they shall have just as much reference to the candidates' attendance at practice and
faithfulness at training as the running ability.
(3). That each team shall be composed of four men.
(4). That the distance of said race shall be one mile.
Very truly yours,
R. CURZON HOFFMAN, JR.,
W. CORNWELL SMITH,ARTHUR R. PADGETT,
J. FRED. HUNTER,
Jos. TOWNSEND ENGLAND,
LUTHER M. R. WILLIS,
THEODORE E. STRAITS,

A VISITOR.
The past summer had many bright days for
me, for I spent June, July, August, and
September on my father's farm in Frederick
County. The day which will always remain
in my memory as the never-to-be-forgotten,
fun-giving day is that on which "My Visitor,"
as my father calls him, came.
In the early morning and forenoon I worked
in the fields, hay-making, and in return for
my morning's labor I was promised the use of
our excellent riding horse for that evening.
In the afternoon I noticed my horse had lost
a shoe, so I took him down to the village to
be shod. While waiting at the blacksmithshop, I was called over to the country store
to get a 'phone .message. This message was
rather strange; "Tell Mr. Mun a y that
So-and-so will be up on the evening train,"
the clerk said that he did not catch the name.
After attending to some errands in the
village, I rode out to my home and delivered
the message. No one in the family had given
any one out of the vicinity an invitation and
no one knew who was coming and we all were
more or less amused at the curtness of such a.
message. Much to my sorrow I was informed
that they would need the horse promised me,
since he was what we termed the "station
wagon horse," to take the large dayton to the
station and bring back the visitors. No one
knew whether there really was anyone coming
or someone was one playing a joke on us so
we prepared for three people. The spare
rooms were all ready, supper on the table for
the guests, or rather, unexpected visitors, and
everything was prepared for their arrival.
About time for the train to come in the
man drove down with my horse and the
station wagon. When the train came in he
looked around for our visitors but none came
and he was just about to drive off when the
freight agent called out. Here's your party.
Of course, the whole family was anxious to
know who was coming and all were out
watching for their arrival. I, being a little
more anxious and put out than the rest, was
the first to find out that no one was on the
front seat of the wagon but the driver. I ran
out to the front and asked who it was and he
said, "They are in the back." I looked and
saw only a crate and asked him "Where?"

"There," said he, pointing to the box I took
it out and in doing so my hand slipped in a
crack and touched a fuzzy, hairy something
which gave a low whine. Then it dawned
upon me what it was. It was a through-bred
St. Bernard puppy promised me by a friend
sometime before. While very much put out
and provoked, the whole family at once saw
the funny side of the affair and my mother
said, "My best bed linen all put out on the
beds for a dog."
I however, was not disappointed, for after
I had made my dog comfortable I went and
got my horse and had a long, beautiful, and
never-to-be-forgotten horseback ride.—M.

THE DANCE.
The second dance of the Cotillon Club was
held on Friday, the thirty-first of January.
From the point of view of the students, it was
one of the most successful ever given. Everybody was there, and "everybody was happy."
Old and distinguished Alumni danced
around and bumped into green young Freshmen and then the Freshmen, not to be outdone,
bumped into them. A few professors were
there, and great excitement was aroused when
a foolish Junior broke up one of them. Suppressed whispers were heard in the hall, and
the young lady who was broken up remarked
in a wise tone:
"I'll bet you flunk your next French
exam."
Of course, we can't say just who the professor was, but that night he wore his usual
cheery smile.
And then there was the barn dance. Some
knew it and some didn't, but everybody danced
it. A few beginners got tumbles, but soon
they got on to it and everybody was in the
swing, perspiring and grinning together.
A few of the professors' wives were there to
chaperon and lend dignity to the occasion.
The students owe to these ladies a debt of
thanks for their unfailing support of the dances.
All in all, it was a great success, and credit
is due to the Cotillon Club for the care taken.
May the next dance on April 24th be as good
as the last one.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE MUSICAL CLUBS.
The Musical Clubs are at last taking on
definite shape and beginning the season's
round of concerts. On the twenty-second of
January a very successful concert was given at
the Johns Hopkins Medical School. A large
proportion of the clubs turned out. The Glee
Club, under the able leadership of Mr. Ruth,
reminded one of the palmy days of old when
thd clubs were in such a flourishing condition.
It is with pleasure that we can note that once
more they seem to arouse the same enthusiasm
among the students and are in such excellent
shape.
On the twenty-sixth of February a concert
will be given at St. David's Church, at Roland
Park, and two others will be given in the near
future, one at the Sparrow's Point Club and
the other at the Sheppard-Enoch Pratt Hospital. The dates for these, however, have not
yet been decided upon.
Then, on the thirteenth of March comes
their red-letter day. A joint concert with the
Woman's College will be held at McCoy Hall.
This will be the first large concert held in
Baltimore by the Musical Clubs for some time,
and everybody in the University should be
there, and bring someone with them, too.
This should be a great success, and the
students should support it.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

POETS OF TODAY.
INTRODUCTORY.
I purpose to write a series of sketches of
those living men who by the high and enduring quality of their work are justly entitled to
the name of Poets, as distinguished from the
ever-swarming hoard of writers of verse.
Thirty years ago such an undertaking as mine
would have been, and was, a task involving
deep and thorough knowledge of the works of
several of the greatest poets of the nineteenth
century. In 1877 Tennyson, Browning,
Arnold, Swinburne, Rossetti and Morris were
all alive and all writing. Today but one of
this illustrious group is alive and he has
passed the alloted time of life.
In glancing over the literary field today, we
find that no one man can lay claim to
absolute pre-eminence. There is, with the
exception of Swinburne, (of whose work by
the way I do not intend to treat in this series)
no great poet living; that is, great as Keats or
as Tennyson was great; but there are several
poets of recognized worth and ability. Of
these most are among the last survivors of
the Age of Tennyson, "the Victorian Age"
and two are of the new era which is slowly
and uncertainly beginning to shape itself
today.
Of the Victorian Poets Mr. Austin Dobson
is the best known, and is most conspiciously
identified with the past. Mr. William Watson's greatest work—his elegies, his epigrams,
and such poems as a "A Child's Hair"—
were written long ago. Mr. Alfred Austin,
writer of charming prose and infinitely less
pleasing verse, is associated with the literary
squabbles of the '70's. Mr. Meredith has
been so long considered as the greatest living
novelist that the far-off days when he wrote
"Love in a Valley" and "Modern Love"
seem to belong to. another existance. His
transformation is indeed marvellous. It is
hard to believe that the author of "Diana of
the Crossways" could have written "The
Shaving of Shagpot;" it is equally difficult to
reconcile the facts that "Love in a Valley,"
and "The Egoist" are from the same pen.
But this is a digression, and we must continue
our enumeration. In 1900 Rudyard Kipling
was unquestionably the presiding genius of

English letters. The novelty of his manner
as of his matter gave him that eminence. But,
in the words of a writer at the time, he was
"the genius of the moment" and is so no
longer. Mr. Andrew Lang, perhaps the
most versatile of modern authors, has for long
laid aside his poetic pen, but the work of such
a true poet cannot die and the author of
"Helen of Troy," 'Andromache,"and—more
than all—of the lovely lyric "Who wins his
love," is indeed "a living part of English
Song."
All these men are writers who have made
their reputations in the past, some, as Mr.
Meredith, half a century ago, though perhaps like him only now receiving that
recognition which their own generation fail
to bestow upon them. But beside them,
there is one poet today, in whom we can
clearly see traces of lineal descent from Keats
and from Tennyson—who is the fulfillment
of the wish expressed long since that a poet
would arise combining in his genius the
tongue of Tennyson and a dramatic instinct
which the author of "Becket" had not.
Finally, and perhaps far from least among
these writers, is Mr. Alfred Noyes, of whom
great things are promised. He is as yet very
young, but his youth doth promise much,
and the author of "A Night at St. Helena"
and "The Barrel Organ" may live to be a
shining and abiding light among the stars of
English poetry.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

THE GEORGE WASHINGTON MEET.
Hopkins did herself proud in the first
annual meet of George Washington University,' held January 25th, in Convention Hall,
Washington, for not only did her men score
a goodly number of points in the open events,
but they came home as holders of the
Southern Championship in the two mile
relay.
There were only two teams in the race.
Virkinia withdrew a few days before the meet,
and only George Washington was left to contest the supremacy and they didn't once get
within sight of the prize. "Polly" Brenton,
who led off, came in fully 40 yards ahead of
the man who was trying to run against him.
Burgan the second man was just as rapid,
or his opponent was just as slow, for he
doubled the distance between them. "Mich"
Griffith kept up the good work, and finally
George Stewart, probably with memories of
last year's race against Virginia floating in
his head, "hit up" the pace that killed hope
in the hearts of Washington rooters, and
romped in at least 200 yards ahead.
"Dutch" Breyer, in the mile, had a reputation to live up to, for all Washington is still
talking of the cross-country race that he and
Polly won so handily on New Year's Day.
But "Dutch" was equal to it. The only scratch
man in the event, he passed an opponent or
two every lap, and finally finished in a position a disinterested spectator would have
called second. The judges, however, gave
the place to a man that had surely been
lapped, and Breyer had to be content with a
bronze medal.
Baily got a second place in the 50-yard
dash, open. He won his heat, beat out
Stollenwerck by a foot in the semi-finals, and
was placed in the finals.
Bridgeman, with a handicap of six inches,
got over 10 feet in the pole vault, and would
probably have gone even higher, had he not
broken his pole, and received a fall that so
incapacitated him that he could no longer do
himself justice.
For the other field events, the men were
unplaced, though Schneeberger made a strong
bid for a place in the high jump. There
were no entries in the shot put, for neither
Michael nor Walters, recognized as the best

7

men in the University, have made a pretense
at training, and in accordance with his wellestablished policy, Mr. West did not enter
them.
There was quite a crowd of Hopkins men
at the meet, and on several occasions they
made their presence felt with a rousing
Hullabaloo.
TRACK NOTES.
The months of February and March promise
to be especially rich in track events, for, in
addition to the meets that the 'Varsity will
hold, there will be two open meets at the
Fifth Regiment Armory and several in Washington of a similar character. The annual
Hopkins meet will be held in the "cage" on
Saturday, February 29th. Owing to the size
of the cage, we cannot hope to have as large
a meet this year as we had last year. But it
is hoped that the quality of the events will fill
in this gap. Entry blanks have been sent out
to the colleges and prep. schools in Maryland,
Virginia and Washington, and many of the
best local athletes have expressed their intention of entering, as the whole meet will be
held from scratch. The events will be as
follows:
50-yard dash (open).
50- yard dash (interscholastic).
440-yard dash (open).
440-yard dash (interscholastic).
880-yard run.
Mile run.
16-pound shot-put.
Pole vault.
High jump.
Broad jump.
A number of relay races will also be arranged.
March 14th has been decided as the date on
which the Hopkins open cross-country run
will be held. The course, which will be about
five and one-half miles long, will start and
end at Homewood.
Stollenwerck, of the 'Varsity track team,
has been selected by Mr. Joseph England as
one of the four men who will form the Baltimore team, in the Inter-City relay race

8

between this city and Washington, which
will be held in the Federal Meet at Washington, February 15th. The associates of the
Hopkins man will be John Harrison, of

THE BANQUETS.
When this issue of the NEWS-LETTER
appears two, at least, of the Class Banquets
will have taken place—the Senior Banquet on
Wednesday, February 12th—and the Junior
Banquet the following day. There has been
a good deal of excitement in a quiet way
around the University and the Juniors have
compelled several Freshmen to give their
word not to attend any banquet of their Class
this week. So readily, indeed, have these
promises been forthcoming from the Freshmen that a suspicion has arisen in the minds
of the more judicious of the upper-classmen
that there will be no Freshmen Feed this
week. Just what will happen we don't know,
but things promise to be pretty lively around
here for some days to come. Fuller accounts
of the Banquets will appear in our next issue,
which, by the way, will probably appear next
Friday.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

GEORGE MEREDITH.
[The celebration of the eightieth anniversary of
George Meredith's birth was an event of "almost national importance" (to use the words of one writer
on the subject.) In spite of divers opinions the
majority of readers have agreed that Mr. Meredith's
first great novel "The Ordeal of Richard Feverel"
still remains his masterpiece. The following short
essay on that novel will therefore be appropriate at
this time. The author has a thorough acquaintance
with the works of the novelists of the Victorian
period and his estimate of the greatest novel of the
greatest living English writer will, we feel sure,
prove of interest to many readers.—En.]

RICHARD FRVERAL.
Richard Feverel is generally considered Mr.
Meredith's masterpiece. He has taken a story,
terrible in itself, and he has made it more
terrible by his fearless way of handling it.
The plot is rather complicated, but the main
points are these: Richard, the son of Sir
Austin Peveral, runs away and marries without his father's consent. It is a love match,
pure and simple. Sir Austin refuses to see
his new daughter, but from a sense of justice,
gives his son an income sufficient to support
her properly. After the honeymoon, Richard
conies to London,leaving his wife. In London
he meets a woman—`'an enchantress"—Bella,
her name is, and proves unfaithful to his wife.
Afterwards, overtaken by a wild storm of
remorse, he does not feel worthy to return to
his wife, whom he still loves, so he travels on
the continent. Finally, hearing that a former
friend, Lord Mountfalcon, has been paying
doubtful attentions to his wife, he returns to
England. Meanwhile, Lucy, his wife, has
met Sir Austin and been reconciled with him
and is living at Raynham Abbey, the home of
the Feverels. Now Richard returns to England and goes to Raynham, where, after long
years, he sees his wife and child. The reconciliation is complete, but not so Richard's
ordeal. He must leave his wife in this
supreme hour and meet Lord Mountfalcon.
He tears himself away from his wife and goes
to France. Here he fights Lord Mountfalcon
and is seriously wounded. His wife and
father hear where he is and come to him. But
the long strain has been too much for Lucy;
she cannot stand the hours of watching and
anxiety. She succumbs to brain fever just as
Richard recovers. She dies and Richard lives.
The tragedy is complete.

9

The plot is complete and perfect. There are
no dangling or lost threads. With the death
of Lucy we lose all interest—the book is
finished. Mr. Meredith does not commit the
mistake of Thackeray in the Newcomer—of
adding several chapters to a novel already
completed. To some people the plot appears
unnatural, but these are the people who are
unable to appreciate and understand the
characters.
All the characters, with the possible exception of Sir Austin, are real, are people all of
us have met. That Sir Austin, with his
Scientific Theory, Aphorisms, System and the
rest, could exist, seems to me impossible.
That a real man, with human feeling, could
look at that last supreme tragedy and turn
away complaining that his grandson is fed by
a bottle, is beyond the bounds of human
imagination. To Sir Austin life was but a
complex system, of which he and his were
mere passive members, but with their duty to
their race to fulfil. This was his goal in life.
Richard's wife was dead. His son was the
future lord of Raynham Abbey, and to him
all must be sacrificed. The story is called a
History of a Father and Son, and the father,
in order that the story may exist, is made
unnatural.
Richard is the most misjudged character in
the book. Some people cannot understand
why he refused to return to his wife. Two
reasons could have prompted his course of
action: One, the fact that .for purely selfish
reasons he did not wish to go back to her, he
was tired of her. The second is the true
reason, the reason expressed in those immortal lines, "May God give me the purity to
be worthy of the good in her, and give her the
patience to find , out the good in me."
Richard was governed by a high sense of
honor. For a moment Bella had swept him
off his feet, but his better nature was bound
to assert itself. When Richard came to his
senses he was conscious of being unworthy to
return to his wife. He felt that he had sinned
and must pay the price of his sin. He must
pass through his ordeal. He goes a7way.
Tormented by a guilty conscience he travels,
but always he feels compelled and forced on
by a high sense of honor. Hearing of Lord
Mountfalcon's attention to his wife, he returns

10

THE NEWS-LETTER.

to England. Then comes the crucial test and
Richard comes out triumphant. His life's
happiness may be wrecked, but, having sinned
once, and expiated his sin, he will hereafter
stand clear in his own mind. He goes to
France and the rest ensues.
The other characters of the book are less
important, but none the less powerful. Adrian
is a magnificent portrait of a type well known
in society. He is not confined to England;
wherever there is a refined and polished state
of society, there are Adrians.
Lucy is womanly, intensely womanly. She
can give up her all to a man and then, when
deserted, can pardon and condone his faults.
Lady Blandish and Mrs. Berry form a queer
antithesis. Both are people met with in everyday life. Lady Blandish seems to be a character created by Mr. Meredith to lend him
support when he finds his story lagging or his
characters grown weak.
But one of the strongest and truest characters in the entire book is Clare. Her story is
true, terribly and sweetly true. Married to a
man whom she does not love, she must keep a
brave face to the world till the long-wished-for
peace comes to her. Dickens may appeal to
the emotions of many by the careful and wellcalculated phrases of Old Curiosty Shop;
Thackeray may move many hearts by the
death of Colonel Newcome; Charles Read may
bring tears to many eyes by that story of a
life full of sorrow and suffering, and yet inspired by a divine hope—The Cloister and
the Hearth—the true story of a great man.
Yet to me none of these have the same depth
of feeling and pathos expressed in that one
chapter—'Clare's Dairy. Mr. Meredith handles
a simple fact in a simple manner. It is so
simple, it is true, so true, that to read it
brings tears.
The Ordeal of Richard Feverel is not one
tragedy but a series of them. Everything is
the natural consequence of what has gone before it. The characters are driven on as by
Nemesis. The "System" could have but one
• result.
From the first that was apparent. Mr.
Meredith appreciated this when, after the
marriage, Adrian says," "So die the System!
And now let the prophets roar! He dies
respectably in a marriage bed, which is more

than I should have told of the monster."
Mean-time, he gave the cake a dramatic tap,
'I'll go sow nightmares." After Iliad read the
first dozen chapters I realized that some great
tragedy was inevitable. It is a book of suffering. Even Sir Austin suffered in silence.
The book is remarkably strong in its hold
upon the reader. A lady once told me that
she first read it when crossing the Atlantic.
When she finished the last chapter sbe took
the bobk, and in sheer anger threw it far out
into the ocean. The genuine power of the
book is well shown by this incident. No book,
unless its power were real, and were accomplished with real people in a real plot, could
produce such an effect.
The tragedy in Richard Eererel is not in
Lucy's dying, it is in Richard's living.
"Have you ever noticed the expression in the
eyes of blind men? That is just how Richard
looks, as he lies there silent in his bed—striving to image her on his brain." There is
the real tragedy in the book.
The place of Richard Feverel in English
Literature is hard to define. That it is
literature and of the highest type, there is no
doubt. Many consider The Egoist by Mr.
Meredith the superior of Richard Feverel, but
I do not feel that the two books are to be
compared. I consider Richard Feverel the
masterpiece of Mr. Meredith and one of the
greatest novels in the entire language.
Mr. Meredith's style is naturally abstruse
and difficult to read, but he is at his best.
When I finished The Egoist, I felt that I had
accomplished quite a task, but when I finished
Richard Feverel my first thought was to read
it over again. The style here is superior to
that of any of Mr. Meredith's other novels,
with the possible exception of Diana of the
Cross-ways.
No praise can be too high for the merit of
the novel. The faults are not easily perceived.
The narrative is very slow in progressing. It
is practically half through before the real
story commences. But this space is not wasted.
We are prepared for the tragedy to come; yet
when it does come, we are stunned by its
truth.
